comment.author: 36899742@N00
comment._content: Winfield S. Huppuch (not Huppuck) was a good friend and business partner of Gov. Dix, who named him a public service commissioner. Ref: query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9A00E3DE1E3EE0... John Alden Dix was Governor of New York from January 1911 to December 1912. Ref: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Alden_Dix. I'm intrigued by the posters rather carelessly taped to the wall in the background, one of them seriously torn.

comment.author: 38118807@N07
comment._content:
Winfield A. Huppuch was from Sandy Hill, Washington County, N.Y.;  He worked in Hudson Falls, Washington County, N.Y. as a Democrat.  He was also a National Democratic candidate for U.S. Representative from New York 23rd District in 1896.  He later became the New York Democratic state chair from 1910 to 1911 and a delegate to Democratic National Convention from New York in 1912, 1916,1920 (alternate), 1928, 1932, and 1936.  He was also a delegate to New York convention to ratify 21st amendment in 1933.  His burial location unknown.

I really like this picture because it really shows the difference in politicians back then and now.  Politicians back then didn't really smile, while politicians today smile a lot.
